text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Sort of like this is different than the Elida which is always in your system. You take it every day. The chemo is in your system, but it peaks, you know, kind of seven to 10 days. You're like, “yeah, I don’t feel so great. I'm not gonna run the marathon.” But then you kind of come down and you're like, “oh, okay, great. It's three weeks later, and I feel great right in time for me to give you the next treatment. Doctor: It’s the roller coaster that I'm not sure you're really looking forward to where you rise up again. But we're hoping that it's not as severe. You know, part of the goal for development of any new medicine is that you hope it's better than the current one. Patient: Okay. Family Member 1: What about sleeping? He’s having trouble sleeping right now? Doctor: No, do you think it has something to do with the steroids, Dexamethasone that you're taking? Because that kind of wakes people up. Patient: No. Ever since I've been on Erlida I've had trouble sleeping. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah. It just takes me forever to- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -get to sleep. Doctor: When was the last time you took that medication? Patient: The Erlida?

text: Family Member: No. Aggression. Patient: The aggression. Yeah. Family Member: Aggression. Doctor: Right. I wouldn’t say it’s the only thing that it’s doing because that’s doing a lot already. Patient: Uh,hum. Doctor: It’s not just slowing the progression. It is actually killing cancer that’s already there as well. So it is actively killing cancer and starving it of testosterone. You are correct in the sense that um we don’t think that this hormone therapy can eradicate all the cancer leading to a cure so that if you stopped the therapy the cancer would not come back. So we do think that it’s a very, very good treatment that reduces remissions, causes remissions – Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: - in more than ninety percent of the people, probably ninety-five, ninety-eight percent of the people, but the remissions are not permanent they’re not long-lasting. On average, they last anywhere from three to five years, that is an average. In many Patients they last longer than that and in some Patients they last less than that. Patient: See that’s that’s my concern with hormonal um as opposed to, and I guess I have to rely on you for your knowledge as far as what would be the best uh um method of treatment for me because ah the hormonal, I know, it it’s there and I know that it’s proven to do, you know, uh to slow progression. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The only place they run into problems is if somebody comes with you know five-hundred things in the bowel, and we’re putting this radiation in cancer, in terms of next to the bone cells, those people mostly get bone marrow problems. But in regard to you, I would expect probably not from the bone marrow. Family Member: Can you get him in this? Doctor: Well the German thing is you know unfortunately you’d have to pay for it. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it’s not a study.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
